t: Job 7
Job’s Life Seems Futile
“Is*pn not man forced to labor on earth, And*ln are*i not*i his days like the days of a hired man?
As*ln a slave who pants for the shade, And*ln as a hired man who eagerly waits for his wages,
So*ln am I allotted months of vanity, And*ln nights of trouble are appointed me.
When*ln I lie down I say, ‘When*ln shall I arise?’ But*ln the night continues, And*ln I am continually tossing until dawn.
My*ln flesh is clothed with worms and a crust of dirt, My*ln skin hardens and runs.
My*ln days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle, And*ln come to an end without hope.
“Remember*ln that my life is but*i breath; My*ln eye will not again see good.
The*ln eye of him who sees me will behold me no longer; Your*ln eyes will*i be*i on me, but I will not be.
When*ln a cloud vanishes, it is gone, So*ln he who goes down to Sheol does not come up.
He*ln will not return again to his house, Nor*ln will his place know him anymore.
“Therefore*ln I will not restrain my mouth; I*ln will speak in the anguish of my spirit, I*ln will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
Am*ln I the sea, or the sea monster, That*ln You set a guard over me?
If*ln I say, ‘My bed will comfort me, My*ln couch will ease my complaint,’
Then*ln You frighten me with dreams And*ln terrify me by visions;
So*ln that my soul would choose suffocation, Death*ln rather than my pains.
I*ln waste away; I will not live forever. Leave*ln me alone, for my days are but*i a breath.
What*ln is man that You magnify him, And*ln that You are concerned about him,
That*ln You examine him every morning And*ln try him every moment?
Will*ln You never turn Your gaze away from me, Nor*ln let me alone until I swallow my spittle?
Have*ln I sinned? What have I done to You, O*ln watcher of men? Why*ln have You set me as Your target, So*ln that I am a burden to myself?
Why*ln then do You not pardon my transgression And*ln take away my iniquity? For*ln now I will lie down in the dust; And*ln You will seek me, but I will not be.”
